columns.text: In this exercise, we are going to learn about abandonment decisions.

To start with, let us define abandonment value. 

**Abandonment value** is the amount of cash the firm would have earned if the investment is abandoned. 

In making a decision if the investment should be abandoned or not, the concept of net present value is used. 

The **net present value (NPV)** is the present value of initial investment or cash outflow less the present value of the cash inflows.

If the NPV is lower than the salvage or residual value of the investment, then it can be liquidated.

Here are the parameters to solve the problem : 


|Given | | 
|--|--| 
|Initial investment |$14,000,000 | 
|Required net working capital (NWC) |$900,000 | 
|Revenue |$10,100,000 | 
|Operating Expenses |$3,800,000 | 
|Tax rate |38% | 
|Discount rate |13% | 
|Useful life of project |4 years | 

- The required net working capital is fully recoverable at the end of the project.

## Requirement 1

We are asked to compute the project's net present value. 

The net present value is solved as follows: 

  

$$\textbf{NPV}=\text{PV of Cash Inflows}-\text{Initial Cash Outflow}$$

The initial cash outflow is deducted from the present value of cash inflows to determine the net present value.

Whereas, the present value of cash inflows is solved as follows: 

  

$$\textbf{PV of Cash Inflows}=\text{Cash Inflow}\times\text{PV Factor}$$

The cash inflows are multiplied by the present value factor to determine the present value of cash inflows.

To start with, let us solve the initial cash outflow: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Initial Cash Outflow}&=\text{Initial Invesment}+\text{Required NWC}\\[15pt]
&=\$14,000,000+\$900,000\\[15pt]
&=\$14,900,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sum of the initial invesment and required net working capital is the initial cash outflow. 

Therefore, the initial cash outflow is $14,900,000.

Now, we compute the depreciation of the project using the straight-line method of depreciation.  

Annual depreciation is computed as follows: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\frac{\text{Cost}}{\text{Useful life}}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{\$14,000,000}{4}\\[10pt]
&=\$3,500,0000
\end{aligned}$$

The cost is divided by the useful life of the project to determine the annual depreciation. 

Hence, the annual depreciation is $3,500,000.

Then, let us solve the annual after-tax profit: 

 

$$\begin{array} {l r}
\text{Revenue}&\$\hspace{5pt} 10,100,000\\
\text{Less: Operating Expense} & (3,800,000)\\
\text{Less: Depreciation}  &(3,500,000)\\ \hline
\text{Pre-tax Profit} & 2,800,000\\
\text{Less: Tax (38\%)} & (1,064,000)\\ \hline
\text{After-tax Profit} &\$\hspace{5pt} 1,736,000 \\ \hline\hline
\end{array}$$

The depreciation and operating costs are deducted from revenue to determine the pre-tax profit. The tax is deducted to arrive at the after-tax profit. 

Therefore, the annual after-tax profit is $1,736,000.

After solving the annual after-tax profit, the annual cash flow for Years 1 to 3 is solved as follows: 

 

$$\begin{array} {l r}
\text{After-tax Profit}&\$\hspace{5pt} 1,736,000\\
\text{Add: Depreciation} & 3,500,000\\ \hline
\text{Cash Flow} &\$\hspace{5pt} 5,236,000 \\ \hline\hline
\end{array}$$

The depreciation is added back to the revenue since it is a non-cash expense. 

Thus, the annual cash flow for Years 1 to 3 is $5,236,000.

For Year 4, the cash flow is solved as follows: 

 

$$\begin{array} {l r}
\text{After-tax Profit}&\$\hspace{5pt} 1,736,000\\
\text{Add: Net Working Capital }&900,000\\
\text{Add: Depreciation} & 3,500,000\\ \hline
\text{Cash Flow} &\$\hspace{5pt} 6,136,000 \\ \hline\hline
\end{array}$$

The required net working capital at the beginning of the project is added back because this amount is recoverable at the end of the project. 

Therefore, the cash flow at Year 4 is $6,136,000.

After solving the annual cash flow, the present value of cash inflow at Year 1 is solved as follows:

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Yr1 : PV of CF }&=\$5,236,000\times0.885\\[15pt]
&=\$4,633,860
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the present value of cash flow at Year 1 is $4,633,860.

Next, the present value of cash inflow at Year 2 is solved as follows:

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Yr2 : PV of CF }&=\$5,236,000\times0.7831\\[15pt]
&=\$4,100,311.60
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the present value of cash flow at Year 2 is $4,100,311.60.

Then, the present value of cash inflow at Year 3 is solved as follows:

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Yr3 : PV of CF }&=\$5,236,000\times0.6931\\[15pt]
&=\$3,629,071.60
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the present value of cash flow at Year 3 is $3,629,071.60.

Now, the present value of cash inflow at Year 4 is solved as follows:

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Yr4 : PV of CF }&=\$4,633,860\times0.6133\\[15pt]
&=\$2,841,946.34
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the present value of cash flow in Year 4 is $2,841,946.34.

After solving the annual present value of cash inflows, we get the total amount below: 

 

$$\begin{array} {l r}
\text{Year 1}&\$\hspace{5pt} 4,633,860\\
\text{Year 2} & 4,100,311.60\\
\text{Year 3} & 3,629,071.60\\
\text{Year 4} & 2,841,946.34\\ \hline
\textbf{Total PV of CI} &\bf\$\hspace{5pt} 15,205,189.54 \\ \hline\hline
\end{array}$$

The annual present value of cash inflows is added to determine the total value. 

Thus, the total present value of cash inflows is $ 15,205,189.54.

## Requirement 2

We are required to compute the net present value of the project assuming it is abandoned after only one, two, or three years. 

The market value of the project over the years is illustrated below: 


|Year |Market Value | 
|--|--| 
|1 |$8,900,000 | 
|2 |$7,700,000 | 
|3 |$5,300,000 | 
|4 |0 |

The equation of salvage value is illustrated below: 

 
$$\textbf{Salvage Value}=\text{NWC}+[\text{MV}-[(\text{MV-CV})\times\text{TR}]]$$

Where: 

- NWC - Net Working Capital
- MV - Market Value
- CV - Carrying Value
- TR - Tax rate

### Year 1

First, let us solve the carrying value of the equipment in Year 1: 


$$\begin{array} {l r}
\text{Cost}&\$\hspace{5pt} 14,000,000\\
\text{Less: Accum. Dep. } & (3,500,000)\\ \hline
\textbf{Carrying Value} &\bf\$\hspace{5pt} 10,500,000 \\ \hline\hline
\end{array}$$


The accumulated depreciation for one year is deducted from the cost to determine the carrying value of the project at Year 1. 

Therefore, the carrying value of the project at Year 1 is $10,500,000.

Now, the cash flow is solved as follows: 

 

$$\begin{array} {l r}
\text{After-tax Profit}&\$\hspace{5pt} 1,736,000\\
\text{Add: Depreciation} & 3,500,000\\
\text{Add: Salvage Value} & 10,408,000\\ \hline
\text{Cash Flow} &\$\hspace{5pt} 15,644,000 \\ \hline\hline
\end{array}$$

The salvage value and depreciation are added back to determine if the project is abandoned at Year 1. 


Therefore, the cash flow in Year 1 is $15,644,000.

After solving the cash flow, the present value of cash inflow at Year 1 is solved as follows:

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Yr1 : PV of CF }&=\$15,644,000\times0.885\\[15pt]
&=\$13,844,940
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the present value of cash flow at Year 1 is $13,844,940.

### Year 2

First, let us solve the carrying value of the equipment in Year 2: 


$$\begin{array} {l r}
\text{Cost}&\$\hspace{5pt} 14,000,000\\
\text{Less: Accum. Dep. } & (7,000,000)\\ \hline
\textbf{Carrying Value} &\bf\$\hspace{5pt} 7,000,000 \\ \hline\hline
\end{array}$$


The accumulated depreciation for two years is deducted from the cost to determine the carrying value of the project in Year 2. 

Therefore, the carrying value of the project in Year 2 is $7,000,000.

Now, the cash flow for Year 1 is solved as follows: 

 

$$\begin{array} {l r}
\text{After-tax Profit}&\$\hspace{5pt} 1,736,000\\
\text{Add: Depreciation} & 3,500,000\\ \hline
\text{Cash Flow} &\$\hspace{5pt} 5,236,000 \\ \hline\hline
\end{array}$$

The depreciation is added back to the revenue since it is a non-cash expense. 

Thus, the cash flow for Year 1 is $5,236,000.

Now, the cash flow for Year 2 is solved as follows: 

 

$$\begin{array} {l r}
\text{After-tax Profit}&\$\hspace{5pt} 1,736,000\\
\text{Add: Depreciation} & 3,500,000\\
\text{Add: Salvage Value} & 8,334,000\\ \hline
\text{Cash Flow} &\$\hspace{5pt} 13,570,000 \\ \hline\hline
\end{array}$$

The salvage value and depreciation are added back to determine if the project is abandoned at Year 2. 


Therefore, the cash flow in Year 2 is $13,570,000.

After solving the annual cash flow, the present value of cash inflow at Year 1 is solved as follows:

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Yr1 : PV of CF }&=\$5,236,000\times0.885\\[15pt]
&=\$4,633,860
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the present value of cash flow at Year 1 is $4,633,860.

Next, the present value of cash inflow at Year 2 is solved as follows:

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Yr2 : PV of CF }&=\$13,570,000\times0.7831\\[15pt]
&=\$10,626,667
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the present value of cash flow at Year 2 is $10,626,667.

After solving the annual present value of cash inflows, we get the total amount below: 

 

$$\begin{array} {l r}
\text{Year 1}&\$\hspace{5pt} 4,633,860\\
\text{Year 2} &10,626,667\\ \hline
\textbf{Total PV of CI} &\bf\$\hspace{5pt} 15,260,527 \\ \hline\hline
\end{array}$$

The annual present value of cash inflows is added to determine the total value. 

Thus, the total present value of cash inflows is $ 15,260,527.

### Year 3

To start with, let us solve the carrying value of the equipment in Year 3: 


$$\begin{array} {l r}
\text{Cost}&\$\hspace{5pt} 14,000,000\\
\text{Less: Accum. Dep. } & (10,500,000)\\ \hline
\textbf{Carrying Value} &\bf\$\hspace{5pt} 3,500,000 \\ \hline\hline
\end{array}$$


The accumulated depreciation for three years is deducted from the cost to determine the carrying value of the project in Year 3. 

Therefore, the carrying value of the project in Year 3 is $3,500,000.

Now, the cash flow for Years 1 and 2 is solved as follows: 

 

$$\begin{array} {l r}
\text{After-tax Profit}&\$\hspace{5pt} 1,736,000\\
\text{Add: Depreciation} & 3,500,000\\ \hline
\text{Cash Flow} &\$\hspace{5pt} 5,236,000 \\ \hline\hline
\end{array}$$

The depreciation is added back to the revenue since it is a non-cash expense. 

Thus, the cash flow for Years 1 and 2 is $5,236,000.

Now, the cash flow for Year 3 is solved as follows: 

 

$$\begin{array} {l r}
\text{After-tax Profit}&\$\hspace{5pt} 1,736,000\\
\text{Add: Depreciation} & 3,500,000\\
\text{Add: Salvage Value} & 5,516,000\\ \hline
\text{Cash Flow} &\$\hspace{5pt} 10,752,000 \\ \hline\hline
\end{array}$$

The salvage value and depreciation are added back to determine if the project is abandoned at Year 3. 


Therefore, the cash flow in Year 3 is $10,572,000.

After solving the annual cash flow, the present value of cash inflow at Year 1 is solved as follows:

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Yr1 : PV of CF }&=\$5,236,000\times0.885\\[15pt]
&=\$4,633,860
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the present value of cash flow at Year 1 is $4,633,860.

Next, the present value of cash inflow at Year 2 is solved as follows:

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Yr2 : PV of CF }&=\$5,236,000\times0.7831\\[15pt]
&=\$4,100,311.60
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the present value of cash flow at Year 2 is $4,100,311.60.

Next, the present value of cash inflow at Year 3 is solved as follows:

 
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Yr3 : PV of CF }&=\$10,752,000\times0.6931\\[15pt]
&=\$7,452,211.20
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the present value of cash flow at Year 3 is $7,452,211.20.

After solving the annual present value of cash inflows, we get the total amount below: 

 

$$\begin{array} {l r}
\text{Year 1}&\$\hspace{5pt} 4,633,860\\
\text{Year 2} & 4,100,311.60\\
\text{Year 3} & 7,452,211.20\\ \hline
\textbf{Total PV of CI} &\bf\$\hspace{5pt} 16,186,382.80 \\ \hline\hline
\end{array}$$

The annual present value of cash inflows is added to determine the total value. 

Thus, the total present value of cash inflows is $ 16,186,382.80.

It is advisable to abandon projects before the end of their useful life if the net present value is greater as compared to the net present value if it is disposed of at the end of their useful life. 

Of the computed net present values if the project is abandoned in Years 1-4, the net present value in Year 3 is the greatest. Therefore, in Year 3, this project maximized its value to the firm.
